revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name = DH.9 |image = Airco_D.H.9.jpg |caption = Airco D.H.9 }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type = [[Bomber]] |manufacturer = [[Airco]] |designer = [[Geoffrey de Havilland]] |first flight = July 1917 |introduced = 1917 |retired = 1920 |primary user = [[Royal Air Force]] |more users = [[RNAS]], [[Royal Flying Corps|RFC]]. |number built = 4,091 |variants with their own articles = [[Airco DH.9A]]
[[Airco DH.9C]]
[[Westland Walrus]] }} |} The '''Airco DH.9''' (from [[Geoffrey de Havilland|de Havilland]] 9) - also known after 1920 as the '''de Havilland DH.9''' - was a [[United Kingdom|British]] bomber used in the [[World War I|First World War]]. A single-engined [[biplane]], it was a development of [[Airco]]'s earlier, highly successful [[Airco DH.4|DH.4]] and was ordered in very large numbers for Britain's [[Royal Flying Corps]] and [[Royal Air Force]]. Its engine was unreliable, and failed to provide the expected power, giving the DH.9 poorer performance than the aircraft it was meant to replace, resulting in heavy losses, particularly over the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]]. The subsequently-developed [[Airco DH.9A|DH.9A]] had a more powerful and reliable American [[Liberty L-12]] engine. ==Design and development== The DH.9 was designed by [[Geoffrey de Havilland|de Havilland]] for the [[Airco|Aircraft Manufacturing Company]] in 1916 as a successor to the [[Airco DH.4|DH.4]]. It used the wings and [[Empennage|tail unit]] of the DH.4 but had a new [[fuselage]]. This enabled the [[Aviator|pilot]] to sit closer to the [[Air gunner|gunner/observer]] and away from the [[Piston engine|engine]] and fuel tank. The other major change from the DH.4 was the choice of the promising new [[Beardmore Halford Pullinger|BHP/Galloway]] ''Adriatic'' engine, which was predicted to produce 300 hp (224 kW) and so give the new aircraft adequate performance to match enemy fighters. By this time, as a result of attacks by German bombers on London, the decision was made to almost double the size of the [[Royal Flying Corps]], with most of the new squadrons planned to be equipped with [[bomber]]s.Bruce 2 April 1956, p.387. Based on the performance estimates for the DH.9 (which were expected to surpass those of the DH.4), and the similarity to the DH.4, which meant that it would be easy to convert production over to the new aircraft, massive orders (4,630 aircraft) were placed. The prototype (a converted DH.4) first flew at [[Hendon]] in July 1917.Jackson 1987, p.97. Unfortunately, the [[Beardmore Halford Pullinger|BHP]] engine proved unable to reliably deliver its expected power, with the engine being derated to 230 hp (186 kW) in order to improve reliability. This had a drastic effect on the aircraft's performance, especially at high altitude, with it being inferior to that of the DH.4 it was supposed to replace. This meant that the DH.9 would have to fight its way through enemy fighters, which could easily catch the DH.9 where the DH.4 could avoid many of these attacks. While attempts were made to provide the DH.9 with an adequate engine, with aircraft being fitted with the [[Siddeley Puma]], a lightened and supposedly more powerful version of the BHP, with the Fiat A12 engine and with a 430 hp (321 kW) [[Napier Lion]] engine, these were generally unsuccessful (although the Lion-engined aircraft did set a [[Flight altitude record|World Altitude Record]] of 30,500 ft (13,900 m) on 2 January 1919Jackson 1987, p.100.) and it required redesign into the DH.9A to transform the aircraft. ==Operational history== To boost the rate of production, quantity orders for the DH.9 were also placed with Alliance, G & J.Weir, Short Brothers, Vulcan, [[Waring & Gillow]] and National Aircraft Factories No. 1 and No. 2. The first deliveries were made in November 1917 to [[No. 108 Squadron RAF|108 Squadron]] [[Royal Flying Corps|RFC]] and it first went into combat over France in March 1918 with [[No. 6 Squadron RAF|6 Squadron]], and by July 1918 nine squadrons operational over the [[Western Front (World War I)|Western Front]] were using the type. The DH.9's performance in action over the Western Front was a disaster, with heavy losses incurred, both due to its poor performance and to engine failures, despite the prior derating of its engine. Between May and November 1918, two squadrons on the Western Front (Nos. [[No. 99 Squadron RAF|99]] and [[No. 104 Squadron RAF|104]]) lost 54 shot down, and another 94 written off in accidents.Mason 1994, p.84. Nevertheless, on 23 August 1918 a DH9 flown by Lieutenant [[Arthur Spurling|Arthur Rowe Spurling]] of 49 Squadron, with his observer, [[Frank Bell (aviator)|Sergeant Frank Bell]], single-handedly attacked thirty [[Fokker D.VII]] fighters, downing five of them.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} Captain [[John Stevenson Stubbs]] managed 11 aerial victories in a DH9, including the highly unusual feat of [[balloon buster|balloon busting]] with one.http://www.theaerodrome.com/aces/england/stubbs2.php Retrieved 1 May 2011. The DH.9 was also more successful against the Turkish forces in the [[Middle Eastern theatre of World War I|Middle East]], where they faced less opposition, and it was used extensively for coastal patrols, to try to deter the operations of [[U-boats]]. Following the end of the First World War, DH.9s operated by [[No. 47 Squadron RAF|47 Squadron]] and [[No. 221 Squadron RAF|221 Squadron]] were sent to southern [[Russia]] in 1919 in support of the [[White movement|White Russian]] Army of [[Anton Ivanovich Denikin|General Denikin]] during the [[Russian Civil War]]. The last combat use by the RAF was in support of the [[1920 conflict between British forces and Somaliland dervishes|final campaign]] against [[Mohammed Abdullah Hassan]] (known by the British as the "Mad Mullah") in [[Somalia]] during January—February 1920.Bruce 13 April 1956, p.424. Surprisingly, production was allowed to continue after the end of the war into 1919, with the DH.9 finally going out of service with the [[RAF]] in 1920. Following the end of the First World War, large numbers of surplus DH.9s became available at low prices and the type was widely exported (including aircraft donated to [[Commonwealth]] nations as part of the [[Imperial Gift]] programme). The [[South African Air Force]] received 48 DH.9s, and used them extensively, using them against the [[Rand Revolt]] in 1922. Several South African aircraft were re-engined with [[Bristol Jupiter]] radial engines as the M'pala, serving until 1937.Jackson 1987, p.102. ==Civilian use== [[File:G-AUED.jpg|thumb|DH-9 G-AUED modified with a cabin for use as an airliner]] Because of the large number of surplus DH.9s available after the war many were used by air transport companies. They provided a useful load carrying capability and were inexpensive. Early air services between [[London]], [[Paris]] and [[Amsterdam]] were operated by DH.9s owned by [[Aircraft Transport and Travel]]. A number of different conversions for civil use were carried out, both by Airco and its successor, the [[de Havilland|de Havilland Aircraft Company]], and by other companies such as the [[ADC Aircraft|Aircraft Disposal Company]].Jackson 1973, p.50-52. Some radial powered DH.9Js continued in use until 1936.Jackson 1973, p.56. ==Variants== *'''DH.9''' - Revised version of the [[Airco DH.4|DH.4]] with the pilot and observer/gunner placed closer together (3,024 production aircraft built with others built in Belgium and Spain). *'''[[Airco DH.9A|DH.9A]]''' - (also referred to as the '''Nine-Ack''') was designed for [[Airco]] by [[Westland Aircraft]] to take advantage of the 400 hp (298 kW) American [[Liberty L-12]] engine. Apart from the new engine and slightly larger wings it was identical to the DH.9. Initially it was hoped to quickly replace the DH.9 with the new version, but the shortage of Liberty engines available to the RAF limited the new type's service in the First World War, and it is best known as a standard type in the postwar RAF, serving as a general purpose aircraft for several years. 2,300 DH.9As were built by ten different British companies. *'''DH.9B''' - Conversions for civilian use as three-seaters (one pilot and two passengers) *'''[[Airco DH.9C|DH.9C]]''' - Conversions for civilian use as four-seaters (one pilot and three passengers) *'''DH.9J''' - Modernised and re-engined conversions using the 385 hp (287 kW) [[Armstrong Siddeley Jaguar]] III [[radial engine]]. Used by the De Havilland School of Flying. [[File:HP 17.png|thumb|Handley Page H.P. 17 showing slots]] *'''DH.9J M'pala I''' - Re-engined conversions carried out by the [[South African Air Force]]. Powered by a 450 hp (336 kW) [[Bristol Jupiter]] VI radial piston engine. *'''M'pala II''' - Re-engined conversions carried out by the South African Air Force, powered by a 480 hp (358 kW) Bristol Jupiter VIII radial piston engine. *'''Mantis''' - Re-engined conversions carried out by the South African Air Force, powered by a 200 hp (149 kW) [[Wolseley Viper]] piston engine. *'''Handley Page HP.17''' - A DH.9 experimentally fitted with slotted wings, tested 1920-1. Barnes 1976, p.211-213. *'''USD-9/9A''' - DH.9s manufactured in the United States by the [[US Army]]'s [[Engineering Division]] and [[Dayton-Wright Airplane Co|Dayton-Wright]]. (1,415 ordered, only four built){{cite web|url=http://contrails.iit.edu/history/Huffman/H-part06.pdf|title=From Huffman Prairie To The Moon, The History of Wright-Patterson Air force Base|number=Part 6|pages=184–186|quote=Plans called for the Curtiss Aeroplane and Moto Corporation of Buffalo, New York, to manufacture 4,000 USD-9As. The order was cancelled, however, when Allied victories in France during the summer of 1918 forecast Germany's ultimate defeat...at least four USD-9A airplanes were manufactured at McCook, but none were built by a contractor.|publisher=WADC/WADD Digital Collection at the Galvin Library, IIT|year=1986|ISBN=978-0160022043}} == Operators == ===Military operators=== {{acopmap|DH 9|DH.9 operators}} ;{{flag|Afghanistan|1919}} *[[Afghan Air Force]] - 18 aircraft, including 16 built by [[Duks Aircraft Works]], acquired from 1924. ;{{AUS}} *[[Royal Australian Air Force]] - One used by the RAAF from 1920 to 1929. **No. 1 Flying Training School RAAF ;{{BEL}} *[[Belgian Air Force]] - 18 aircraft.Bruce 13 April 1956, p.423. ;{{flag|Canada|1921}} *[[Canadian Air Force (1918-1920)|Canadian Air Force]] ;{{BOL}} *[[Bolivian Air Force]] ;{{CHL}} *[[Chilean Air Force]] - Received 20. ;{{EST}} *[[Estonian Air Force]] operated 13 from 1919 to 1933 .Gerdessen 1982, p.76 ;{{flag|India|British}} (Part of [[Imperial Gift]]) [[File:Greek aircraft during the Greco-Turkish War.jpg|thumb|Greek DH-9]] ;{{flag|Greece|old}} *[[Hellenic Naval Air Service|Royal Hellenic Naval Air Service]]Bruce 13 April 1956, p.425. ;{{flag|Kingdom of Hejaz}} :The Kingdom of Hejaz received 9 DH.9s and 2 DH.9Cs between 1921 and 1924. Five remained in existence (although not airworthy) in 1932.Andersson ''Air Enthusiast'' July/August 2004, pp. 39–42. ;{{IRL}} *Irish Air Service *[[Irish Air Corps]] ;{{LAT}} *[[Latvian Air Force]] ;{{NLD}} *[[Royal Netherlands East Indies Army Air Force]] - operated 36, some of which were re-engined with [[Pratt & Whitney Wasp]] [[radial engine]] withdrawn in 1934. ;{{NZL}} *[[Royal New Zealand Air Force]] - Three Airco DH.9s in service with the [[New Zealand Permanent Air Force]] from 1923 to 1929 as advanced training aircraft. ;{{flag|Paraguay}} *[[Paraguayan Air Force]] ;{{PER}} *[[Peruvian Air Force]] ;{{POL}} *[[Polish Air Force]] - 20 received in 1920, used during the [[Polish-Soviet war]], until 1929.Kopański, Tomasz Jan: ''Samoloty brytyjskie w lotnictwie polskim 1918-1930'' (British aircraft in the Polish air force 1918-1930), Bellona, Warsaw 2001, ISBN 83-11-09315-6, p.55-62 (in Polish) ;{{flag|Romania}} *[[Royal Romanian Air Force]] ;{{flagicon|Spain|1785}} [[Kingdom of Spain]] *[[Spanish Air Force]] ;{{flag|South Africa|1928}} *[[South African Air Force]] - Part of the [[Imperial Gift]]. Some locally modified with Jupiter engines and named '''Mpala'''. ;{{USSR}} *[[Soviet Air Force]] ;{{SUI}} *[[Swiss Air Force]] [[File:De Havilland D.H.9 Ganimet.jpg|thumb|Turkish DH-9]] ;{{TUR}} *[[Turkish Air Force]] - four aircraft, in service from 1921 to 1924. ;{{UK}} *[[Royal Flying Corps]] *[[Royal Naval Air Service]] *[[Royal Air Force]] ;{{flag|United States|1912}} *[[American Expeditionary Force]] *[[United States Marine Corps]] ;{{flag|Uruguay}} *[[Uruguayan Air Force]] ===Civil operators=== ;{{AUS}} *[[Qantas]] ;{{BEL}} *[[Sabena]] ;{{DEN}} *[[Det Danske Luftfartselskab]] ;{{NLD}} *[[KLM]] ;{{flag|Romania}} *[[TAROM|SNNA]] ;{{flagicon|Spain|1785}} [[Kingdom of Spain]] *Cia Espanola del Trafico Aereo ;{{UK}} *[[Aircraft Transport and Travel]] *[[Handley Page Transport]] ; [[File:Bikaner.svg|20px]] [[Bikaner|Bikaner State]] * [[History of Bikaner#Ganga Singh|Maharaja Ganga Singh]] ==Surviving aircraft== [[File:DH.9 F1258 LeB 05.07R.jpg|thumb|DH.9 ''F1258'' at the [[Musée de l'Air et de l'Espace]], Paris Le Bourget]] Of the thousands of DH.9s built, only a few have survived to be preserved. ''F1258'' is displayed at the ''Musée de l'Air et de l'Espace'' in [[Paris]],[http://www.mae.org/index.php?id=378 DH.9]. ''Musée de l'Air et de l'Espace''. Retrieved 11 April 2008 with a second DH.9 being preserved at the [[South African National Museum of Military History]],Blake, Arthur.[http://rapidttp.com/milhist/vol016ab.html "Colours in the Sky"] ''Military History Journal'' - Vol 1 No 6, June 1970. The South African Military History Society. Retrieved 11 April 2008 while ''G-EAQM'', the first single-engined aircraft to fly from the United Kingdom to Australia is preserved in the [[Australian War Memorial]] at [[Canberra]].Jackson 1987, p.125.[http://cas.awm.gov.au/photograph/P02270.029 AWM Collection Record: P02270.029] Australian War Memorial. Retrieved 11 April 2008 The remains of three DH.9s were discovered in India in 2000,[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/in_pictures/6577629.stm In pictures: 'Elephant stable' bomber] ''BBC.co.uk'', 21 April 2007. Retrieved 11 April 2008 one of which is displayed at the [[Imperial War Museum Duxford]], and another in the process of being restored to flying condition.[http://www.historicaircraftcollection.ltd.uk/dh9/ DH-9] ''Historic Aircraft Collection Ltd''. Retrieved 11 April 2008 ==Specifications (D.H.9 (Puma Engine))== [[File:Airco de Havilland DH.9 dwg.jpg|thumb|Airco DH.9 drawing]] {{aircraft specifications |plane or copter?=plane |jet or prop?=prop |ref=''The British Bomber since 1914''Mason 1994, p.86. |crew=two |capacity= |length main= 30 ft 5 in |length alt= 9.27 m |span main= 42 ft 4⅝ in |span alt= 12.92 m |height main= 11 ft 3½ in |height alt= 3.44 m |area main= 434 ft² |area alt= 40.3 m² |airfoil= |empty weight main= 2,360 lb |empty weight alt= 1,014 kg |loaded weight main= |loaded weight alt= |useful load main= |useful load alt= |max takeoff weight main= 3,790 lb |max takeoff weight alt= 1,723 kg |more general= |engine (prop)=[[Armstrong Siddeley Puma]] |type of prop= piston engine |number of props= 1 |power main= 230 hp |power alt= 172 kW |power original= |max speed main= 98 kn |max speed alt= 113 mph, 182 km/h |cruise speed main= |cruise speed alt= |never exceed speed main= |never exceed speed alt= |stall speed main= |stall speed alt= |range main= |range alt= |ceiling main= 15,500 ft |ceiling alt= 4,730 m |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main= |loading alt= |power/mass main= |power/mass alt= |more performance= *'''Climb to 10,000 ft:''' 18 min 30 sec |endurance=4½ hours |guns=Forward firing [[Vickers machine gun]] and 1 or 2 × Rear [[Lewis gun]]s on [[scarff ring]] |bombs=Up to 460 lb (209 kg) bombs |avionics= }} ==See also== {{aircontent |related=*[[Airco DH.4]] *[[Airco DH.9A]] |similar aircraft= *[[Breguet 14]] |lists= |see also= }} ==References== ===Notes=== {{Research help|Mil}} {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} * Andersson, Lennart. Pages 385—388, 392. * Bruce, J.M. "[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1956/1956%20-%200422.html The De Havilland D.H.9: Historic Military Aircraft: No. 12, Part II]". London: Putnam, Third edition 1987. ISBN 0-85177-802-X. * Mason, Francis K. ''The British Bomber Since 1914''. London: Putnam Aeronautical Books, 1994. ISBN 0-85177-861-5. * Winchester, Jim, ed. ISBN 1-84037-386-5. {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Airco DH.9}} *[http://www.britishaircraft.co.uk/aircraftpage.php?ID=572 British Aircraft Directory Entry for Airco DH.9] *[http://www.airspaceduxford.org.uk/html/infocus/infocus_news11.htm DH9 at Imperial War Museum, Duxford] {{De Havilland aircraft}} {{Handley Page aircraft}} {{Engineering Division aircraft}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Airco DH.009}} [[Category:British bomber aircraft 1910–1919]] [[Category:Airco aircraft|DH.009]] [[Category:Single-engined tractor aircraft]] [[Category:Biplanes]]
